title: Samira Ahmed takes on the BBC in landmark equal pay case
text:
The BBC presenter Samira Ahmed is to challenge the broadcaster in a landmark equal pay case on Monday, claiming she was paid 85% less than her male equivalent.

Ahmed will demand hundreds of thousands of pounds in backpay for her work on the BBC programme Newswatch, which she has presented since 2012. She will claim that her male equivalent was Jeremy Vine for his work on the BBC’s Points of View between 2008 and 2018.

Vine was paid £3,000 an episode of Points of View between 2008 and January 2018, while Ahmed received £440 per programme of Newswatch, according to Ahmed’s case, the National Union of Journalists said in a statement. This had risen to £465 in 2015, before being reduced as the BBC switched presenters on to employment contracts.

Gender pay gap at its widest for women in their 50s, study reveals Read more

Both shows were presenter-led programmes of almost 15 minutes and offered the public the opportunity to air their views on BBC content. However, the corporation’s legal team will argue that the two presenters were not doing the same or similar work.

The presenter has secured an agreement from the BBC for full backdated pay for her work on Radio 4’s Front Row and Radio 3’s Night Waves/Free Thinking, the NUJ said, where the pay gap between Ahmed and male comparators was 50% and 33% respectively.

Facebook Twitter Pinterest According to Samira Ahmed’s case, Jeremy Vine received £3,000 per episode of Points of View. Photograph: David Mirzoeff/PA

Ahmed will be accompanied at court by other prominent female BBC presenters in a show of solidarity.

“I love my job on Newswatch, despite it being difficult and challenging,” Ahmed said in a statement. “I know that it is an important part of demonstrating the BBC service to all its audiences and the licence fee payers.

“I have a sense of pride working for a public service broadcaster which seeks to represent the diversity of Britain and its licence fee-payers.

“On the back of my BBC ID card are written the BBC values which include ‘we respect each other and celebrate our diversity’ and ‘we take pride in delivering quality and value for money’. I just ask why the BBC thinks I am worth only a sixth of the value of the work of a man for doing a very similar job.”

The case will be heard at central London employment tribunal over the next seven days.
description: Presenter claims unfair treatment after getting ‘one-sixth’ pay of Jeremy Vine
